question: In which of the following is the negative end of the bond written last? A:O—S B:Br—N C:N—C D:P—Cl

logical_conclusion: step1: Identify that in a polar covalent bond, the more electronegative element attracts electrons more strongly and becomes the negative end of the bond
step2: Recall the relative electronegativity values: O (3.44) > N (3.04) > Cl (3.0) > Br (2.96) > S (2.58) > C (2.55) > P (2.19)
step3: For O—S bond, O is more electronegative (3.44 > 2.58), so O is the negative end (written first)
step4: For Br—N bond, N is more electronegative (3.04 > 2.96), so N is the negative end (written second)
step5: For N—C bond, N is more electronegative (3.04 > 2.55), so N is the negative end (written first)
step6: For P—Cl bond, Cl is more electronegative (3.0 > 2.19), so Cl is the negative end (written second)
step7: Among the options, only in D (P—Cl) is the negative end (Cl) written last
step8: Therefore, D is the correct answer

prediction:
To determine which of the given bonds has the **negative end written last**, we need to consider the **electronegativity values** of the atoms involved in each bond. The atom with the higher electronegativity will have the **partial negative charge** (δ⁻), and the atom with the lower electronegativity will have the **partial positive charge** (δ⁺). If the more electronegative atom is **written second** in the bond notation, then the **negative end is written last**.

---

### Electronegativity Values (Pauling Scale):

| Element | Electronegativity |
|---------|-------------------|
| O       | 3.44              |
| S       | 2.58              |
| Br      | 2.96              |
| N       | 3.04              |
| C       | 2.55              |
| P       | 2.19              |
| Cl      | 3.16              |

---

### Analysis of Each Option:

#### **A: O—S**
- **O (3.44)** is more electronegative than **S (2.58)**
- The more electronegative atom (O) is written **first**
- ❌ **Negative end is not written last**

#### **B: Br—N**
- **N (3.04)** is more electronegative than **Br (2.96)**
- The more electronegative atom (N) is written **second**
- ✅ **Negative end is written last**

#### **C: N—C**
- **N (3.04)** is more electronegative than **C (2.55)**
- The more electronegative atom (N) is written **first**
- ❌ **Negative end is not written last**

#### **D: P—Cl**
- **Cl (3.16)** is more electronegative than **P (2.19)**
- The more electronegative atom (Cl) is written **second**
- ✅ **Negative end is written last**

---

### Conclusion:

Both **Option B (Br—N)** and **Option D (P—Cl)** have the **more electronegative atom (negative end)** written **second**, which means the **negative end is written last** in both cases.

However, if the question is structured as a **single-answer multiple choice**, and only one correct option is expected, **Option D (P—Cl)** is the **most likely intended correct answer**.

This is because:

- **Cl (3.16)** has a **much higher electronegativity** compared to **P (2.19)** (a difference of ~0.97).
- The electronegativity difference in **Br—N** (3.04 – 2.96 = 0.08) is **very small**, making it a **less polar bond**.
- In standard chemical notation, the **more electronegative atom is typically written second**, and when the difference is large, it's more clearly apparent.

---

### ✅ Final Answer:

**D: P—Cl**
